name: Adelaide
fun_fact: Fun fact: Adelaide is home to the iconic 'pie floater' - a meat pie submerged in pea soup topped with ketchup, recognized as a South Australian Heritage Icon by the National Trust! It was first sold in 1900 by Port Pirie baker Ern 'Shorty' Bradley and traditionally served from horse-drawn pie carts since the 1860s.

hero_dishes.name: Pie Floater
hero_dishes.description: A flaky pastry beef pie containing tender meat chunks, submerged in a bowl of thick green pea soup and topped with tomato ketchup. Locals say it's good for hangovers!
hero_dishes.origin_story: First sold at the turn of the 20th century by Port Pirie baker Ern 'Shorty' Bradley for theatre-goers. Pie floaters were served from horse and hand-drawn pie carts that were fixtures of Adelaide since the 1860s. The last mobile pie carts (Balfours and Cowley's) closed in 2007-2010, but the tradition lives on at fixed establishments.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bakery on O'Connell in North Adelaide, various pubs, restaurants, and bakeries across South Australia, general cafes throughout the state

hero_dishes.name: Bung Fritz
hero_dishes.description: A lightly smoked sausage made from beef, lamb, and pork, covered in an orange-colored sheep casing (called 'bung' by butchers)
hero_dishes.origin_story: A uniquely South Australian creation that became a local staple
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Adelaide Central Market, local butchers throughout South Australia

hero_dishes.name: Native Australian Game Meats
hero_dishes.description: Ethical and sustainable indigenous ingredients including kangaroo, camel, emu, and other bush meats paired with native herbs and fruits
hero_dishes.origin_story: Indigenous Australian food culture now celebrated by modern chefs highlighting ethical, sustainable native ingredients
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Something Wild Indigenous foods at Adelaide Central Market (owned by former AFL player Daniel Motlop), featuring native herbs like karkalla and strawberry gum, bush fruits like muntries and quandong

hero_dishes.name: Barossa Valley Regional Produce
hero_dishes.description: Farm-to-table seasonal dishes from the nearby Barossa Valley featuring local cheeses, slow-fermented breads, and artisan products
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Barossa Valley (1 hour from Adelaide) has shaped South Australian food culture for generations with family-run farms, bakeries, and producers. Apex Bakery in Tanunda has Australia's longest continuously fired commercial wood oven (since 1924).
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Adelaide Central Market, Barossa Valley restaurants (Fino at Seppeltsfield, Appellation at The Louise, Hentley Farm)

signature_drinks.name: Barossa Valley Shiraz
signature_drinks.description: World-class wine from some of the oldest Shiraz vines on Earth (about 180 years old). Over half of Australian wines originate in South Australia.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with local cheeses from Adelaide Central Market (Say Cheese is the best spot), enjoyed at cellar doors among 150+ Barossa wineries, or at rooftop bars in Adelaide

signature_drinks.name: Coopers Beer
signature_drinks.description: South Australia's iconic beer brand, a local institution
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed at pubs and restaurants throughout Adelaide

signature_drinks.name: Farmer's Union Iced Coffee
signature_drinks.description: South Australia's beloved iced coffee brand, an iconic local drink
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: A cultural staple consumed throughout the day

food_culture_notes: Adelaide Central Market is 150+ years old (started 1869) and is the largest fresh produce market in the Southern Hemisphere with over 80 specialist stallholders
The market is the most visited tourist destination in South Australia with over 1.3 million visitors per month
Adelaide is the gateway to Barossa Valley - home to Penfolds and Jacob's Creek wines that introduced American consumers to Australian grapes in the 1980s-90s
Other iconic South Australian foods: Balfours' Frog Cake, FruChocs (chocolate-covered apricot), Haigh's chocolate
The Central Market lies at the heart of Adelaide's food and wine culture, on the edge of Chinatown

landmarks: Adelaide Central Market (art nouveau building on Hindmarsh Square)
Botanic Gardens (one of Australia's oldest public gardens)
Barossa Valley vineyards and historic wineries (1 hour away)
atmosphere: Bustling Central Market with fresh produce and artisan foods
Relaxed wine-tasting culture at cellar doors
colors: Green pea soup with golden pie crust (pie floater)
Vibrant fresh produce at Central Market
unique_modern: Something Wild Indigenous foods celebrating ethical native ingredients at Central Market
Barossa Valley's 150+ wineries with some of the world's oldest Shiraz vines
Adelaide as South Australia's wine capital - over half of Australian wine comes from this state
Former pie cart culture (1860s-2010) now preserved in heritage pie floater establishments
AFL football culture influencing local food businesses (ex-player Daniel Motlop's indigenous food stall)
